data.title: 7 Emirates of United Arab Emirates - A Country Guide
data.meta_description: UAE (United Arab Emirates) is a cumulation of seven emirates: Dubai, Sharjah, Abu Dhabi, Fujairah, Ras Al Khaimah, Ajman, and Umm Al Quain. Dubai and Abu Dhabi are the most tourist-centric emirates and the most popular places to visit.
data.text:
UAE (United Arab Emirates) is a cumulation of seven emirates: Dubai, Sharjah, Abu Dhabi, Fujairah, Ras Al Khaimah, Ajman, and Umm Al Quain. Dubai and Abu Dhabi are the most tourist-centric emirates and the most popular places to visit. However, the remaining emirates also boast with many fun activities, unique sights, and truly amazing offerings.

The article below aims to highlight all seven emirates and gives you many insights into each. Happy reading.

7 Emirates of the United Arab Emirates and their rulers:

Seven royal families rule all seven emirates in the UAE, here's a quick look at the ruling families and the current Emirs of the UAE's seven emirates:

Abu Dhabi: Al Nahyan - His Highness Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan

Dubai: Al Maktoum - His Highness Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum

Sharjah: Al Qasimi - His Highness Dr Sheikh Sultan bin Mohammed Al Qasimi

Ajman: Al Nuaimi - His Highness Sheikh Humaid bin Rashid Al Nuaimi

Umm Al Quwain: Al Mualla - His Highness Sheikh Saud bin Rashid Al Muâ€™alla

Ras Al Khaimah: Al Qasimi - His Highness Sheikh Saud bin Saqr Al Qasimi

Fujairah: Al Sharqi - His Highness Sheikh Hamad bin Mohammed Al Sharqi

Abu Dhabi â€“ The Capital Emirate

Abu Dhabi is the capital of the UAE and is known as one of the wealthiest cities in the world, home to the luxury lifestyle spot. It is the largest of the seven emirates and has the unique name "land of the gazelle". With various marvels like The Louvre and Yas Island, Abu Dhabi has many offerings that will leave you in awe and are relatively hassle-free in comparison to Dubai.

Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque

The Sheikh Zayed Grand Mosque is a symbol of glorious Islamic architecture.

It is one of the largest mosques in the world and blends the UAE's values of Islamic traditions.

Qasr al Hosn

Qasr Al Hosn, also known as Al Hosn Palace.

Qasr Al Hosn is the oldest and most significant building in Abu Dhabi, holding the city's first permanent structure: The Watchtower.

The palace has a watchtower constructed in the 1790s to safeguard the island settlements of Abu Dhabi.

Presently, the palace has been transformed into a museum, with displays of artifacts and archival materials dating back to as far as 6000 BC

Ferrari World Abu Dhabi

Ferrari World Abu Dhabi is an indoor theme park located on Yas Island in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.

It is the world's first Ferrari-themed park and features Formula Rossa, the world's fastest roller coaster.

You can enjoy the thrill of intense speed at Ferrari World Abu Dhabi.

Louvre Abu Dhabi

Louvre Abu Dhabi is the first universal museum in the Middle East. It depicts historical, sociological, and cultural artifacts in its galleries.

It is located in the heart of Saadiyat Cultural District.

Mangrove Parks

Worlds away from Abu Dhabi's skyscrapers and bustling city nightlife, lies a serene paradise and a reservoir of biodiversity called Mangrove National Park.

This biodiversity hotspot includes salt marshes, mudflats, and algal communities.

As you stroll through this forest, you'll find yourself filled with a profound sense of realization. Gazing upon the peaceful waterway, the rich canopy of trees, the vibrant wildlife, and beyond, you'll come to appreciate the sheer beauty of nature.

Dubai â€“ The Vibrant Multicultural Destination

Dubai is a place known for its futuristic skyscrapers, vibrant nightlife, famous landmarks, top-notch centralized and secure infrastructures, shopping malls and much more.

Dubai is the â€˜home away from homeâ€™ of more than 200 nationalities.

During the early 1700s, this emirate's economy was primarily dependent on fishing and pearl farming, which was a fascinating aspect. However, around the 2000s, there was a significant shift towards real estate and tourism as the key drivers of its economy.

Many things make Dubai a popular tourist destination, but here are some of the best ones.

Burj Khalifa

The Burj Khalifa is an iconic skyscraper in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, and is the tallest building in the world.

Rising to a staggering 828 meters, the Burj Khalifa is a symbol of modern engineering and architectural marvel.

Offering breathtaking views of the city's skyline and beyond, it is not only a landmark but also a testament to Dubai's ambition and innovation.

The Museum of the Future

Next comes the "Museum of the Future," an architectural masterpiece that embodies the spirit of futuristic design and sustainability.

This museum showcases groundbreaking advancements in various fields, including artificial intelligence, robotics, and sustainable development.

"The Museum of the Future" offers visitors a glimpse into the future, inspiring curiosity, creativity, and dialogue about tomorrow's possibilities.

Palm Jumeirah

Palm Jumeirah is the world's largest man-made island located off the coast of Dubai.

Shaped like a palm tree, with fronds and a trunk, Palm Jumeirah is renowned for its luxurious resorts, pristine beaches, and upscale residences.

Palm Jumeirah offers a lavish lifestyle with stunning ocean views, from high-end shopping and dining to thrilling water sports and leisure activities.

This engineering marvel stands as a testament to Dubai's ambition and innovation in creating extraordinary experiences for residents and visitors alike.

Dubai Mall

In Downtown Dubai, Dubai Mall stands as one of the globe's largest shopping and entertainment complexes.

With over 1,200 retail outlets, spanning over 13 million square feet, it offers an extensive array of shopping choices, including luxury brands and global retailers.

Tourists can also immerse themselves in attractions such as the Dubai Aquarium, VR Park, and the Dubai Ice Rink, ensuring an unforgettable experience in the heart of Dubai.

Al Fahidi District

Situated in central Dubai, Al Fahidi Historical Neighbourhood is celebrated for its rich heritage and traditional architecture.

This charming district boasts well-preserved wind-tower houses, narrow alleyways, and courtyards that showcase Dubai's historic past.

Visitors can explore museums, art galleries, and cultural centers within these historic buildings, offering a fascinating insight into Emirati culture and heritage.

Dubai Opera

Dubai Opera, located in Downtown Dubai, is an arts venue renowned for its architectural splendor, which hosts a diverse range of cultural and entertainment events, including operas, concerts, ballets, and theater productions.

With views of the Dubai Fountain and Burj Khalifa, Dubai Opera offers an unforgettable experience for arts enthusiasts.

Dubai Souks

Dubai Souks are bustling marketplaces known for traditional shopping experiences allowing visitors to immerse themselves in Dubai's rich culture and heritage.

Visitors can explore traditional souks like the Gold Souk and Spice Souk, offering everything from gold jewelry to aromatic spices.

Sharjah â€“ The Cultural Hub

Sharjah is one of the seven emirates of the UAE. With its rich cultural heritage and diverse attractions (museums, art galleries, and historic sites), Sharjah offers a glimpse into the region's history and traditions.

Tourists can explore landmarks such as Sharjah Art Museum, Al Noor Mosque, Sharjah Safari Park and the picturesque Al Qasba waterfront area.

Sharjah Art Museum

Sharjah Art Museum is a cultural institution showcasing a diverse contemporary and traditional art collection.

Located in the heart of Sharjah, it features works by local and international artists, offering insight into the region's artistic heritage.

One can explore rotating exhibitions, permanent collections, and educational programs, making it a must-visit destination for art enthusiasts.

Sharjah Safari Park

The 8000-hectare Sharjah Safari Park is an expansive wildlife sanctuary with diverse ecosystems and animal encounters.

Situated in the heart of Sharjah, the park is home to various species, including giraffes, zebras, lions, and more.

Visitors can enjoy guided tours, educational programs, and interactive experiences, making it an ideal destination for families and nature enthusiasts alike.

Al Noor Mosque

UAE is also famous for its beautiful mosques around but Al Noor Mosque stands apart because of its traditional Ottoman-style architecture

Situated along the Khalid Lagoon, it offers a picturesque setting and is a prominent landmark in the city.

This mosque is a place of rich Islamic culture and history.

Ajman â€“ Traditional Meets Modern

Ajman, one of the smallest emirates among the rest of the 7, is a charming coastal city known for its relaxed atmosphere and cultural attractions.

Ajman has nature-enriched landmarks such as the Ajman Museum, UAE Pygmy Zoo, Al Zorah Nature Reserve, housed in an 18th-century fort, and Ajman Corniche, a scenic waterfront promenade.

With its pristine beaches, vibrant souks, and rich history, Ajman offers a delightful blend of tradition and modernity for travelers to discover.

Ajman Museum

Ajman Museum, situated within an 18th-century fort, is a cultural treasure trove showcasing the heritage and history of the emirate.

This fort served as the residence of Ajmanâ€™s then ruler and was later converted into a museum in 1981 and has since been a place to explore the emirate's lifestyle and culture through historical displays.

Exhibits featuring artifacts, photographs, and interactive displays that offer insights into Ajman's past make this landmark a must-see for tourists.

UAE Pygmy Zoo

The UAE Pygmy Zoo is a groundbreaking attraction in Ajman.

The wildlife park accepts visitors even though some areas are still under construction.

UAE Pygmy Zoo is located near Al Zorah Marina, offering up-close encounters with animals, rides on camels and ponies, and fun interactions with lovely pups, making it a trendy attraction amongst young families.

Al Zorah Nature Reserve

Al Zorah Nature Reserve, in Ajman, UAE, is a pristine coastal sanctuary teeming with diverse flora and fauna.

Spanning over 60 hectares of protected wetlands, it offers nature lovers and outdoor enthusiasts a serene escape.

Visitors can explore the mangrove forests, birdwatching trails, and kayaking opportunities, immersing themselves in the beauty of this ecological haven.

Umm al Quwain â€“ The Fishing Haven

Umm Al Quwain, more minor in population but victorious in the unexplored treasuries, also known for its tranquil ambience and natural beauty.

Fishing is a key contributor to Umm Al Quwain's economy. The emirate exports seafood throughout Europe and the Middle East.

This emirate has rich coastal mangroves on the coast of the Arabian Gulf and many islands that lie to the east of the mainland. The biggest island, Al Seniah, is home to Arabian gazelles, falcons and turtles.

With its pristine beaches, charming mangrove forests, and cultural attractions, Umm Al Quwain offers a peaceful retreat away from the bustle of city life.

Aside from that, the emirate has plenty of other attractions to offer.

Falaj al Mualla Fort

Falaj Al Mualla Fort, located in Umm Al Quwain, UAE, is a historic landmark showcasing the region's rich heritage.

Built in the 19th century, the fort was a strategic defense structure and administrative center, but after its restoration in 2015, the fort now serves as a museum.

Visitors can explore its well-preserved architecture, including watchtowers and courtyards, offering insights into the emirate's history and culture.

Ed-Dur Site

The Ed-Dur Site is an ancient archaeological site dating back to the Iron Age.

Visiting the site's ruins, which include tombs, residential structures, and a water cistern, offers a glimpse into the daily life of its ancient inhabitants. This aspect makes it a must-visit for tourists seeking knowledge about a rich history.

Umm Al Quwain National Museum

Housed in a renovated fort, the museum features exhibits on maritime history, traditional Emirati life, historical wars, and archaeological discoveries.

Visitors can explore artifacts, photographs, and interactive displays, offering a comprehensive look into Umm Al Quwain's rich cultural legacy.

Ras al Khaimah â€“ The Adventure Zone

Ras al Khaimah which translates to "top of the tent" in Arabic, is a captivating destination known for its natural sceneries, sprawling deserts and towering mountain ranges.

Visitors can explore landmarks such as Jebel Jais, the UAE's highest peak, and historical sites like Dhayah Fort.

Some of the emirate's most prominent attractions include the following:

Jebel Jais

Jebel Jais is the highest mountain range in the United Arab Emirates, reaching 2,000 meters.

It offers breathtaking views and thrilling adventures, including the world's longest zipline, the Jebel Jais Flight.

Explorers can enjoy activities such as hiking, camping, and scenic drives, making it a popular destination for nature lovers and adventure seekers.

Wadi Shawka

Wadi Shawka is a seasonal watercourse in the Hajar Mountains of Ras Al Khaimah and is the perfect example of a seasonal river bed that transforms as rain falls over the mountains.

Wadi Shawka translates into a 'powerful valley' and is a breathtaking area of natural beauty that conceals secrets dating seven millennia ago.

The wadi has a strong agricultural history. As you explore, you'll see many abandoned ancient settlements replaced with modern farms.

National Museum of RAS al Khaimah

The museum serves the ruling family residences as all other museums in the other 7 emirates did.

In 1987, it was converted into a museum with an impressive collection of artefacts, archaeological finds, interactive displays, and multimedia presentations, providing insights into various aspects of Ras Al Khaimah's culture, traditions, economy, and lifestyle throughout the ages.

Fujairah â€“ The Land of Wild Waters and Wadis

Fujairah is the last emirate on our list but certainly not the least. It is distinguished by its rugged landscape surrounded by the Al Hajar Mountains and has a sandy 70-km coastline. The emirate receives visitors throughout the year due to its relatively low summer temperatures.

Here are some of the best attractions in the emirate.

Fujairah Beaches

Fujairah Beach is on the Gulf of Oman, located in the northern part of Fujairah City, Emirate of Fujairah, United Arab Emirates.

Vacationers can explore Fujairah's beaches' underwater wonders through snorkeling and diving, discovering vibrant coral reefs and diverse marine life.

Tim's Reef

Tim's Reef is located off the coast of Fujairah, UAE, and is known for its renowned diving site, vibrant coral reefs, and diverse marine life.

It has visible and calm waters near Snoopy Island, making it ideal for both beginner and experienced divers.

At Tim's Reef, divers can explore the colorful coral gardens, swim alongside tropical fish, and encounter other fascinating marine creatures such as turtles, rays, and moray eels.

Madhab Spring Sulphuric Park

Madhab Spring Sulphuric Park, commonly called Madhab Spring Park, is a natural wonder renowned for its therapeutic waters.

Tourists can immerse themselves in the spring's rejuvenating waters, which are believed to offer various health benefits for the skin and body.

One can enjoy many fun activities, including BBQ, badminton, and swimming. This is a famous family destination.

Wadi Wurayah National Park

Wadi Wurayah National Park spans 220 square kilometers, boasting diverse topography and hosting around 860 species, including 208 plant varieties.

Notable wildlife includes rare species like the Blandford fox, Gordon's wildcat, hedgehogs, and the Arabian tahr, a native mountain goat.

Ornithologists flock to the park for its 94 endangered bird species, while surveys reveal it harbors 24 out of 30 known dragonfly species worldwide.

Visitors can enjoy the park's beautiful waterfalls and unique wildlife, making it a popular destination for conservationists and tourists alike.
